Expectation1: Maintain regular communication with family members
Situation1: The grandmother learns that a family member is dealing with a significant personal crisis.
Expectation2: Write clean, maintainable, and efficient code
Situation2: The new feature is nearly ready but performance warnings appear in code reviews
Story: I sat at my desk, the soft ping of a new message breaking my concentration. My IDE was open, lines of code blinking back at me, the latest feature almost ready to ship. But the code review comments stung—performance warnings, suggestions to refactor, reminders to keep things clean and efficient. My team was counting on me to deliver something solid, something that wouldn’t bog down the system. I flexed my fingers, ready to dive back in, when my phone buzzed again. This time, it was my daughter. Her message was short, but the words hit hard: “Grandma, can you call? It’s about your grandson. He’s not doing well.” My heart twisted. I knew I should call right away, be the steady presence my family needed, especially now. But the code review deadline loomed, and my team was waiting. I stared at the screen, torn between the demands of my work and the needs of my family, feeling the weight of both roles pressing in on me.
